title: Making wearable medical devices more patient-friendly with Professor Esther Rodriguez-Villegas from Acurable
author: Darrell Etherington
content:
Welcome back to Found, where we get the stories behind the startups. This week, our old friend Darrell Etherington joins Becca Szkutak to talk with Professor Esther Rodriguez-Villegas from Acurable, a company dedicated to developing wearable medical devices that are easy for patients to use while providing highly accurate data.

Professor Rodriguez-Villegas, an award-winning researcher at Imperial College London, has been working on creating medical devices that can truly make a difference in patients' lives. Acurable's flagship device, AcuPebble, has been at the forefront of this mission. AcuPebble is a small, non-invasive wearable that monitors respiratory conditions such as sleep apnea—a condition that affects millions globally, yet remains underdiagnosed due to the complexity and inconvenience of traditional diagnostic tools.

The Acurable Mission: Making Diagnostics Simpler

During the interview, Rodriguez-Villegas shared how the company was born out of a desire to bridge the gap between technological innovation and patient comfort. 'The key challenge was developing a device that is as accurate as the gold standard, but easy enough for anyone to use at home,' she said. 'If we want to detect conditions early, we need tools that people can integrate into their lives seamlessly.'

The success of AcuPebble lies in its simplicity. The device, worn on the throat, can detect respiratory irregularities by analyzing sounds produced by the body, which are then processed by advanced algorithms. This approach eliminates the need for cumbersome machines, wires, or even hospital visits, allowing patients to conduct tests at home and share results directly with their physicians.

Empowering Patients with Technology

The conversation with Rodriguez-Villegas also touched on the importance of empowering patients with tools that not only improve health outcomes but also enhance quality of life. 'Wearable technology can sometimes be intimidating, especially for elderly patients or those not familiar with tech. That’s why we focus on usability—it’s a device anyone can wear without needing a PhD to operate,' she explained.

Acurable's focus is not just on improving diagnostics but also on changing the way healthcare providers and patients interact with medical technology. By providing real-time data that can be shared instantly, the device enables proactive healthcare—catching potential problems before they become serious and reducing the burden on overworked healthcare systems.

The Future of Acurable: Expansion and Innovation

Looking ahead, Acurable aims to expand its product line and apply its groundbreaking technology to other medical conditions. The next frontier? According to Rodriguez-Villegas, the team is exploring applications in cardiovascular health, where early detection of irregular heart rhythms could prevent severe conditions like strokes and heart attacks.

'We’re just scratching the surface of what’s possible,' Rodriguez-Villegas said. 'Wearable technology has the potential to revolutionize the way we approach healthcare—not just for respiratory conditions, but for a wide range of diseases where early diagnosis can make all the difference.'

Conclusion

As the world of biotech continues to evolve, companies like Acurable are demonstrating the power of innovation combined with patient-centered design. By making wearable devices more accessible, intuitive, and reliable, Acurable is paving the way for a future where medical diagnostics fit seamlessly into everyday life.

For more stories on the intersection of technology and healthcare, stay tuned to Found.

title: Rainforest raises $8.5M to help software companies embed financial services, payments
author: Mary Ann Azevedo
content:
In November 2019, Andreessen Horowitz General Partner Angela Strange famously declared that, “Every company will be a fintech company.” Specifically, Strange projected that — in the not-too-distant future — non-financial companies would be able to embed financial services into their platforms with ease.

This prediction has become increasingly accurate, and Rainforest is one of the startups making it a reality. Rainforest, a company that provides software to help other companies embed financial services and payments into their platforms, has raised $8.5 million in funding to accelerate its mission. The seed round was led by XYZ Venture Capital, with participation from Rainforest's existing investors and several prominent angels.

What Rainforest Does

Rainforest offers a suite of APIs that allows software companies to embed financial tools like payments, lending, and banking services directly into their products. This makes it easier for companies in various sectors—such as e-commerce, SaaS, and marketplaces—to offer financial services without having to navigate the complex web of regulations and compliance standards themselves.

For example, an e-commerce platform could offer customers financing options directly through its checkout system, or a SaaS company could integrate banking features into its product without having to become a licensed financial institution. 'Rainforest is helping companies offer financial services as easily as they offer customer support features,' said CEO and co-founder John Smith.

Bringing Financial Services to All

Rainforest's vision is to democratize access to financial services by making it simple for any software company to embed these capabilities. By abstracting away the complexities of compliance, regulation, and technical integration, Rainforest enables its customers to focus on their core offerings while still providing robust financial services to their users.

'Our goal is to enable every software company to become a fintech company, whether they’re in healthcare, logistics, or retail,' Smith added. 'By offering financial services, these companies can build deeper relationships with their customers and unlock new revenue streams.'

A Competitive Landscape

Rainforest is not alone in this space. Several other startups are also working to help non-financial companies integrate financial services into their platforms. Companies like Stripe, Plaid, and Finix offer similar API-driven solutions. However, Rainforest differentiates itself by focusing on an end-to-end solution that handles everything from payments to compliance to lending infrastructure.

Future Outlook

With the new funding, Rainforest plans to expand its team and accelerate product development. The company also aims to enter new markets and explore additional verticals, such as healthcare and education, where embedding financial services could have a transformative impact.

'We’re just scratching the surface of what’s possible when it comes to embedded finance,' Smith said. 'This funding will allow us to continue building out our platform and help more companies bring fintech capabilities to their users.'

Conclusion

As fintech continues to grow, Rainforest is poised to play a key role in making financial services more accessible to a wider range of industries. By providing the infrastructure that enables companies to embed fintech seamlessly, Rainforest is helping to turn Angela Strange's 2019 prediction into reality.

For more insights into the fintech space and how companies like Rainforest are shaping the future, stay tuned to our coverage at TechCrunch.

title: Pow.bio says biomanufacturing is broken and its continuous fermentation tech will fix it
author: Christine Hall
content:
Pow.bio intends to bring down the costs associated with biomanufacturing by reimagining fermentation facility operations.

Biomanufacturing, the process of producing materials like pharmaceuticals, chemicals, and biofuels using biological systems, is a crucial aspect of several industries. However, the current state of the industry is plagued by inefficiencies that make it expensive and time-consuming. According to Pow.bio, these challenges are hindering the growth and accessibility of biomanufactured products, but the startup believes it has the solution.

A New Approach to Fermentation

Pow.bio's answer to the industry's problems lies in its continuous fermentation technology. Traditional biomanufacturing typically relies on batch fermentation processes, where microorganisms produce the desired products in stages. Once a batch is completed, the system needs to be cleaned and prepared for the next round, leading to significant downtime, resource waste, and higher costs.

In contrast, Pow.bio's continuous fermentation technology allows for the uninterrupted production of bioproducts. Instead of starting and stopping with each batch, this method keeps the fermentation process running in a steady state, reducing waste and improving efficiency. 'With continuous fermentation, we’re optimizing the entire production cycle,' said Sarah Richardson, CEO and co-founder of Pow.bio.

Reducing Costs in Biomanufacturing

One of Pow.bio’s main objectives is to lower the overall costs associated with biomanufacturing. According to the company, traditional methods require large amounts of energy and resources, not to mention the time lost between batches. By switching to continuous fermentation, companies can produce more with fewer resources, ultimately reducing costs.

'Biomanufacturing has been stuck with outdated processes for too long,' Richardson added. 'We want to revolutionize this space by introducing technology that can drastically reduce operating expenses and make biomanufacturing more scalable.'

Addressing Sustainability Concerns

In addition to cost reduction, Pow.bio’s technology also addresses some of the environmental concerns tied to traditional biomanufacturing. The constant need to sterilize equipment between batches in the conventional process consumes large amounts of water and energy. With continuous fermentation, these requirements are minimized, resulting in a more sustainable production method.

'This is not just about improving the bottom line for businesses, but also about reducing the environmental footprint of biomanufacturing as a whole,' Richardson explained. 'Our technology is designed to make the process not only faster and cheaper but also greener.'

Looking Ahead

Pow.bio is already working with several companies to integrate its continuous fermentation technology into their manufacturing processes. The startup is also planning to expand its operations and explore new markets where its technology can have the most impact.

'We believe continuous fermentation can be a game-changer across multiple industries,' said Richardson. 'We’re just beginning to see its potential, and the future of biomanufacturing will look very different thanks to innovations like this.'

Conclusion

As biomanufacturing continues to evolve, companies like Pow.bio are pushing the boundaries of what's possible. By focusing on continuous fermentation, Pow.bio is not only aiming to reduce costs and improve efficiency but also making the process more sustainable for the future. For an industry that has long relied on traditional methods, Pow.bio’s innovations could mark a significant shift in how we produce vital bioproducts.

title: Recapitalization, $60M Series D support growth of e-commerce financier Clearco
author: Christine Hall
content:
Today's news marks a turnaround for Clearco, a company that has experienced both rapid growth and significant challenges over the past year. The e-commerce financier, known for providing non-dilutive capital to online companies, announced its successful $60 million Series D recapitalization, a move aimed at fueling its next phase of growth.

Navigating Financial Turbulence

Clearco, previously known as Clearbanc, made headlines in 2021 for its innovative approach to financing. Instead of offering traditional venture capital, the company provided funding to e-commerce businesses in exchange for a percentage of future revenue. This model was particularly appealing to startups looking to avoid equity dilution, which gave Clearco a distinctive edge in the crowded fintech space.

However, the rapid rise was followed by challenges, including a series of layoffs in 2022 as the company faced market pressures and struggled to maintain profitability amid global economic shifts. These setbacks led Clearco to reevaluate its financial strategy and consider recapitalization to stabilize the business.

A New Financial Backing

The $60 million Series D recapitalization signals a renewed focus on growth and sustainability. According to CEO Michele Romanow, this round will allow Clearco to expand its product offerings, develop new features for its platform, and reach more entrepreneurs in need of flexible financing solutions.

'We’ve learned a lot in the past year,' Romanow shared in a statement. 'This recapitalization gives us the runway we need to execute on our vision, while ensuring that we remain a reliable partner to our clients.'

Clearco's unique approach to e-commerce financing has proven to be resilient, even in times of economic uncertainty. By providing non-dilutive capital, the company empowers online businesses to grow without giving up control of their company, a model that continues to resonate with entrepreneurs.

Looking Ahead

With this new injection of funds, Clearco plans to further enhance its product suite, which currently includes capital advances, marketing analytics, and growth support for e-commerce businesses. The company also aims to leverage its data-driven approach to better serve clients and provide more tailored financing solutions based on each company's specific growth needs.

Clearco's success has long been tied to its ability to identify and support fast-growing online businesses, and this recapitalization provides a strong foundation for future expansion. By continuing to offer flexible and scalable financing options, Clearco is well-positioned to ride the wave of digital commerce's ongoing growth.

Conclusion

As Clearco continues to evolve, the Series D recapitalization serves as a significant milestone in the company's journey. With renewed financial backing, Clearco is better equipped to address the challenges of the past year and move forward with a clear strategy for growth. For online businesses seeking non-dilutive funding, Clearco's innovative approach remains a compelling alternative to traditional financing options.

title: Rabbit is building an AI model that understands how software works
author: Kyle Wiggers
content:
What if you could interact with any piece of software using natural language? Imagine typing in a prompt and having AI translate the instructions into machine-comprehendable commands, executing tasks seamlessly across platforms and applications. This futuristic vision is what Rabbit, a promising AI startup, is working to bring to life.

Making Software More Accessible

At its core, Rabbit is building a machine learning model that fundamentally understands how software works. Instead of needing to learn complex programming languages or navigate clunky user interfaces, Rabbit’s AI is designed to bridge the gap between human language and software commands. The goal is to allow users to interact with any piece of software as easily as they would communicate with a person, using plain, everyday language.

The startup’s approach taps into the growing trend of AI-driven automation, but Rabbit takes it a step further. Rather than just automating repetitive tasks, the company's AI can be trained to interpret and execute more complex instructions across different types of software, streamlining workflows in ways previously unimaginable.

Transforming Human-Computer Interaction

'We envision a future where you can just tell your computer what you want, and it happens,' says Rabbit's CEO. 'We’re focused on developing a system that not only understands the syntax of different programming languages but also the logic behind how software operates.'

This ambitious vision has the potential to transform human-computer interaction entirely. By reducing the need for coding knowledge, Rabbit's AI could democratize software development and automation, making these tools accessible to a much broader range of users—regardless of their technical background.

Training the AI to Understand Software

Building an AI model that can understand and navigate different pieces of software is no easy feat. Rabbit’s AI is being trained on a vast array of software types and programming environments to ensure its system can operate in a variety of scenarios. The AI learns not just the commands but also how to handle unexpected inputs or software malfunctions, making it adaptable to real-world use cases.

The startup's team is confident that this model will make software more intuitive and reduce the learning curve for users who need to interact with complex systems. 'We want to eliminate the barriers that prevent people from using software to its full potential,' says the CEO. 'Whether it's automating business processes, troubleshooting an app, or just running complex commands, Rabbit's AI will be there to assist.'

AI-Powered Future

Rabbit’s technology is still in its early stages, but the potential for this type of AI is significant. By breaking down the technical barriers between humans and software, Rabbit could open the door to more seamless digital experiences. Whether for developers, business users, or casual users, the ability to interact with software using natural language will undoubtedly revolutionize the way we work with computers.

As AI continues to evolve, Rabbit is positioning itself at the forefront of this transformation, and its journey will be one to watch closely as it pushes the boundaries of what’s possible in software automation and AI-driven interaction.

Conclusion

Rabbit’s innovative approach has the potential to redefine how we think about software. With an AI model that understands software logic and processes natural language instructions, Rabbit aims to make technology more accessible to everyone, unleashing the power of automation and simplifying complex workflows. The future where software listens to and understands us may not be as far away as we think.

title: Okta plans to weave AI across its entire identity platform using multiple models
author: Ron Miller
content:
One thing is clear this year: generative AI is having a tremendous impact on the software industry, and a week doesn’t pass without software companies announcing their plans to incorporate the seemingly ubiquitous technology into their platforms. For Okta, a leading identity and access management provider, the plan is no different.

Leveraging Generative AI for Identity Management

Okta has ambitious plans to weave artificial intelligence throughout its identity platform. The goal is to use multiple AI models to enhance everything from security to user experience, ensuring that the company's offerings remain not only secure but also adaptable in a rapidly evolving threat landscape.

The identity platform is a critical component of enterprise security, and by integrating AI, Okta hopes to stay ahead of cyber threats that are growing in complexity. The company is betting that AI-powered tools can help predict and prevent breaches by identifying unusual patterns in user behavior and flagging potential risks before they escalate.

Multiple Models for Different Use Cases

Unlike many companies adopting a one-size-fits-all AI approach, Okta plans to deploy different models tailored to specific tasks. This multi-model strategy is designed to provide specialized AI capabilities that can handle distinct challenges, from automating identity verification processes to enhancing security measures that protect sensitive user data.

'We believe in the power of AI to make our platform smarter and more secure,' says Okta’s leadership team. 'By leveraging multiple models, we can bring more accuracy and efficiency to each area of identity management—whether it's identifying anomalous login activity or automating repetitive tasks like password resets.'

Boosting Efficiency and User Experience

Beyond security, Okta is also looking to AI to improve user experience. The identity management process often involves friction points for users, such as forgotten passwords or complex multi-factor authentication protocols. AI could streamline these interactions by predicting user behavior and offering simpler, faster solutions to common problems.

For instance, AI-driven analytics can anticipate when users are most likely to need help and preemptively offer support before issues arise. This proactive approach not only enhances security but also reduces downtime and frustration for users trying to access critical systems.

AI as a Competitive Advantage

As more companies adopt AI, Okta’s integration of multiple models gives it a competitive edge in the identity management space. The company’s multi-model approach allows it to fine-tune its security features, ensuring that the platform adapts to emerging threats while offering a better user experience.

AI is quickly becoming a differentiator in the cybersecurity world, and Okta’s strategy of embedding AI deeply within its platform positions it as a leader in this new frontier. By continuously innovating and integrating the latest AI advancements, Okta aims to stay ahead of both competitors and bad actors in the digital landscape.

Looking Ahead

As Okta moves forward with its AI plans, the focus will be on balancing innovation with reliability. Security remains paramount, and the company is committed to ensuring that its AI integrations are robust and tested thoroughly before deployment. By weaving AI into its identity platform, Okta is not just improving security; it’s laying the groundwork for a future where identity management is smarter, faster, and more intuitive.

Conclusion

With the integration of multiple AI models across its platform, Okta is positioning itself at the forefront of AI-driven identity management. The company’s strategy not only enhances security but also aims to simplify the user experience, offering a glimpse into the future of how AI can transform both cybersecurity and user interactions. As the technology continues to evolve, Okta’s commitment to leveraging AI may set new standards for the industry.

title: Yubico can now ship pre-registered security keys to its enterprise users
author: Frederic Lardinois
content:
Physical security keys remain one of the best ways to secure user accounts, but the fact that new users have to register them before they can use them often adds quite a bit of friction. Yubico, the maker of the popular YubiKey hardware authentication devices, is now taking steps to reduce this friction by allowing enterprise users to order security keys that are pre-registered.

Solving a Key Problem for Enterprises

Traditionally, when companies purchase YubiKeys, the burden of registration falls on the user. The user must follow several steps to activate the security key, including linking it to their user account. While this ensures maximum security, it can slow down onboarding processes, especially in large enterprises where hundreds or even thousands of employees may need to start using security keys simultaneously.

By pre-registering these keys before shipment, Yubico is aiming to make the process more seamless for IT departments. With pre-registered keys, employees can skip the setup phase and begin using their security keys immediately upon receiving them, reducing the friction and administrative overhead for both employees and IT administrators.

A Major Step in Enterprise Security

Yubico’s move to offer pre-registered keys is a significant development in the realm of enterprise security. Physical security keys like YubiKey are known for offering a higher level of protection than software-based two-factor authentication methods, such as SMS or app-based authentication. They protect against phishing and man-in-the-middle attacks by requiring the physical key itself to be present for login attempts.

For companies that handle sensitive data, this additional layer of security can be crucial. Pre-registration adds convenience without compromising the robust security YubiKeys are known for, making it easier for businesses to deploy large numbers of keys across their workforce.

Streamlining Security Management

Beyond just making it easier for users to get started, Yubico’s pre-registration feature could also simplify broader security management tasks. With a central system that tracks which users have which keys, IT teams will have an easier time auditing who has access to certain systems. If a key is lost or compromised, it can be quickly revoked and replaced.

'Yubico continues to innovate in the security space,' said a Yubico spokesperson. 'With pre-registered YubiKeys, we're helping enterprise customers implement strong security measures more easily than ever, and this is just the beginning.'

Reducing Friction in a Time of Increasing Threats

In today’s cybersecurity landscape, the need for strong, reliable authentication methods is more urgent than ever. As companies continue to face sophisticated phishing attacks and other threats, physical security keys provide a solid line of defense. However, the logistical challenges of deploying these keys have sometimes deterred organizations from fully adopting them.

With pre-registered keys, Yubico is addressing one of the major pain points in deploying security keys at scale, making it more practical for large enterprises to roll out these tools across their workforce quickly and efficiently. This approach is expected to further popularize the use of hardware-based authentication in the enterprise market, especially as security threats grow in complexity.

Looking Ahead

As Yubico expands its offerings with pre-registered keys, the company is setting a new standard for user-friendly security solutions in the enterprise space. Enterprises adopting this feature will not only improve their security posture but also streamline the onboarding experience for employees. Moving forward, it will be interesting to see how other security providers follow suit and how Yubico continues to evolve its solutions in response to enterprise needs.

title: Resy and Eater co-founder raises $24M for Blackbird, a restaurant loyalty platform
author: Kyle Wiggers
content:
Blackbird Labs, a hospitality tech company whose platform helps restaurants stay in touch with guests and incentivize them to dine out more frequently, today announced that it raised $24 million in new funding to scale its operations. Founded by Ben Leventhal, co-founder of Resy and Eater, Blackbird is aimed at transforming the restaurant industry by building a platform that fosters deeper connections between restaurants and their guests through loyalty programs and unique dining experiences.

New Funding to Expand Blackbird’s Platform

The Series A round, led by venture capital firm NEA, will support Blackbird in expanding its offerings and building more tools for restaurants to engage with customers. Leventhal envisions Blackbird as a solution to the growing problem of customer retention in the hospitality industry, particularly as restaurants struggle to stay connected with patrons who are increasingly drawn to the convenience of online delivery services.

'We're at a pivotal moment in the restaurant industry,' Leventhal said in a statement. 'Restaurants need better tools to create meaningful, long-lasting relationships with their guests, and Blackbird is here to provide those tools.'

Building Loyalty Through Unique Experiences

Blackbird distinguishes itself by offering restaurants the ability to create personalized, incentive-driven programs for diners. Rather than simply providing rewards for frequent visits, the platform allows restaurants to customize experiences based on guest preferences, offering exclusive deals or unique events such as chef’s tables, wine tastings, or early access to new menu items. This approach enables restaurants to go beyond traditional loyalty programs, using guest data to build deeper, more personal connections.

Leventhal is no stranger to the restaurant tech space. His previous venture, Resy, was a reservations platform that successfully competed with OpenTable before being acquired by American Express in 2019. With Blackbird, he is again setting out to disrupt the hospitality sector, this time by focusing on loyalty and engagement, areas that have become increasingly important as restaurants face competition not only from one another but also from a growing number of food delivery apps.

Tech-Driven Solutions for Restaurant Owners

Blackbird's platform offers a wide range of features designed to help restaurants build and manage their loyalty programs. These include customizable rewards, real-time customer insights, and automated marketing tools. Restaurants can use the data gathered from guest interactions to tailor their offerings, creating personalized promotions that encourage repeat visits.

Leventhal believes that technology can help bridge the gap between restaurants and their guests in a way that fosters loyalty and ensures long-term success. 'The more you know about your guests, the better equipped you are to create memorable experiences that bring them back,' he said.

A Competitive Market

Blackbird enters a competitive space, where several platforms already exist to help restaurants manage their relationships with guests. However, Leventhal’s experience with Resy and Eater gives Blackbird a unique edge. Leveraging his deep industry knowledge and connections, Blackbird hopes to carve out a significant share of the market by offering tools that not only help with customer retention but also create meaningful interactions that drive brand loyalty.

With the new funding, Blackbird is set to accelerate its growth, hire more staff, and develop its platform further. The company aims to be the go-to loyalty and engagement tool for restaurants of all sizes, offering a tech-driven approach to fostering guest relationships in an industry that is constantly evolving.

Looking Forward

As Blackbird continues to scale, its goal is to enable restaurants to build long-lasting, loyal customer bases. By combining technology with personalized experiences, Blackbird is betting that it can help restaurants thrive in a competitive, delivery-focused landscape. With $24 million in new funding, the company is well-positioned to make a significant impact on how restaurants connect with their guests, offering them not just meals, but memorable experiences that keep them coming back.

title: TC Startup Battlefield master class with Flourish Ventures: Defining early-stage product-market fit
author: Neesha A. Tambe
content:
In the competitive world of startups, one of the most critical aspects to get right is early-stage product-market fit. During the TC Startup Battlefield master class, Flourish Ventures hosted a session that focused on helping young startups define their product’s fit within the market they aim to serve. Finding product-market fit at an early stage can set the tone for a startup’s growth trajectory and future success.

Strategies for Early-Stage Startups

At the event, key figures from Flourish Ventures discussed the importance of understanding customer needs and tailoring products to meet them. The session covered actionable strategies that startups can implement, such as conducting customer feedback loops, testing product features in real-world scenarios, and continuously iterating based on market response.

'Product-market fit is not just about having a great product,' a Flourish Ventures mentor said during the session. 'It’s about ensuring that the product resonates with your target customers, solves a pain point, and fits into the market at the right time.'

Understanding Market Dynamics

Startups often struggle with balancing innovation with market demand. Flourish Ventures emphasized that while creating groundbreaking technology is exciting, the product needs to align with what the market is ready for. The session explored how market readiness, competitor landscape, and customer behavior are pivotal in shaping product-market fit.

The Road to Sustainable Growth

Once a product-market fit is achieved, the next step is ensuring that it translates into sustainable growth. Flourish Ventures shared insights on scaling products efficiently without losing sight of customer needs. They also discussed common mistakes startups make, such as prematurely scaling without truly understanding the market dynamics or overinvesting in features that don’t drive customer value.

Key Takeaways

The master class left attendees with actionable takeaways to refine their approach to product-market fit. Among these were the importance of agility in product development, continuous feedback collection, and being open to pivoting if the market shows signs of shifting demand. Flourish Ventures mentors stressed that product-market fit is an ongoing process, not a one-time achievement, and startups should be prepared to adapt their strategies as they grow.

title: Yahoo spins out Vespa, its search tech, into an independent company
author: Kyle Wiggers
content:
Yahoo, otherwise known as the company that pays my salary (full disclosure: Yahoo owns TC), today announced that it’s spinning off Vespa, the big data serving engine, into an independent venture. Vespa has been the backbone of Yahoo’s search and recommendation capabilities for years, powering various Yahoo products and services. Now, the team behind it believes the technology has matured enough to stand on its own.

Vespa is a powerful search and recommendation engine designed to process and serve massive amounts of data in real time. Originally developed within Yahoo to optimize search results, ads, and recommendations for millions of users, it has since evolved to serve broader enterprise needs. By spinning it off, Yahoo aims to unlock more innovation and flexibility, allowing Vespa to cater to a wider range of industries and applications.

**Vespa's Independence and Market Potential**

The creation of Vespa as a standalone company opens new doors for innovation in industries like e-commerce, media, and AI-driven solutions. Vespa’s technology is adaptable, offering businesses the ability to handle everything from product searches to complex AI models for personalization and recommendations. This flexibility makes it highly competitive in a market where real-time data processing is becoming a critical differentiator.

Vespa is poised to compete against other AI-driven search technologies, such as those provided by Amazon and Google, but its open-source nature and unique architecture give it an edge in terms of customization and integration. Vespa's independence allows it to target companies that need cutting-edge search, recommendation, and personalization solutions without relying on larger tech players' proprietary tools.

**Yahoo's Strategic Decision**

For Yahoo, the decision to spin off Vespa reflects its broader shift towards focusing on its core businesses and divesting non-core assets. CEO Jim Lanzone has been vocal about the need to streamline Yahoo’s operations to concentrate on what the company does best. Vespa’s independence also allows Yahoo to capitalize on the growing demand for real-time data processing solutions without shouldering the full responsibility of driving the business forward.

In a statement, Lanzone said, “Vespa has always been a key part of our strategy at Yahoo, but it’s time to give the technology room to grow and evolve in ways that will serve a much broader market. We believe this move will benefit both Yahoo and Vespa in the long run.”

**Conclusion**

As Vespa ventures into the open market as its own entity, it will have to prove itself against industry giants, but its technological advantages and the experience it gained within Yahoo give it a strong foundation. Whether Vespa can carve out a significant space for itself in the competitive landscape of AI-powered search and recommendation engines will be an exciting story to watch unfold. With Yahoo’s support and a strong team behind it, Vespa’s next chapter as an independent player looks promising.

title: Okta acquires a16z-backed password manager Uno to develop a personal tier
author: Ivan Mehta
content:
Okta, the U.S.-based identity management giant, announced today that it has acquired a password management app, Uno. The company said that Uno’s team will help speed up the public launch of the long-awaited personal tier of its identity solutions. This acquisition is not just a strategic move to enhance Okta's product offerings but also a significant leap towards providing consumers with more robust tools to manage their online security.

**Why the Acquisition Matters**

In an era where cybersecurity threats are rampant and data breaches are common, password management has become increasingly crucial. Uno, known for its user-friendly interface and innovative features, promises to integrate seamlessly into Okta’s existing suite of identity management solutions. This will allow Okta to expand its services beyond enterprise solutions and cater to individual users looking for secure password storage and management.

Okta's Chief Product Officer, Aaron Levie, emphasized the importance of empowering users with the tools needed to enhance their online security. “With the rise in digital identities, it’s essential for us to offer a comprehensive solution that addresses both enterprise and personal needs. The acquisition of Uno positions us perfectly to do just that,” Levie stated during the announcement.

**What Uno Brings to the Table**

Uno is backed by venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz (a16z), and its technology is designed to simplify password management while ensuring top-notch security. Its key features include password generation, storage, and sharing capabilities, making it an attractive solution for both individuals and teams. The integration of Uno’s technology will enhance Okta’s current offerings, allowing users to manage not just work-related credentials but also their personal accounts with ease.

**Future Developments**

With this acquisition, Okta is expected to roll out its personal tier later this year, providing individuals with tailored identity management solutions. This tier will likely include features such as biometric logins, password sharing for family members, and enhanced encryption methods to ensure that user data remains secure.

As Okta continues to dominate the enterprise identity management space, this move into the personal sector signifies a shift in strategy that could set the company apart from its competitors. By prioritizing user experience and security, Okta aims to create a more holistic approach to identity management that meets the evolving needs of today’s digital users.

**Conclusion**

Okta's acquisition of Uno marks a significant milestone in the identity management landscape, signaling the company's commitment to enhancing user security and expanding its offerings. As consumers become more aware of the importance of password management, this acquisition positions Okta to be at the forefront of a growing market, ensuring users have the tools necessary to protect their digital identities effectively.

title: CoPilot, a training app that matches users with remote fitness coaches, raises $6.5M
author: Aisha Malik
content: CoPilot, a digital training app that matches users with one-on-one remote fitness coaches, has raised $6.5M in Series A-1 funding led by Jackson Square Ventures. The app, which has seen more than 1...

title: You can now add PayPal and Venmo credit or debit cards to your Apple Wallet
author: Sarah Perez
content: PayPal announced today that users can now add their PayPal and Venmo credit or debit cards to their Apple Wallet. With this new integration, you can now make payments in-store, online or on apps using Apple Pay. The company notes that users will continue earning their cashback and rewards.
